_prev_prog_3.Description:
15-2/Cavern #4

A mixture of propylene, propane, ethane, propyne, and propadiene are fed to the distillation section of Process 1.  Ethane is separated from the mixture and sent to a customer for use in their fuel system.  Propane is separated from the mixture and sent to a customer for sale as product.  Propylene is further purified and stored in an underground cavern.  



This site has two splitter column process trains with associated feed and recovery systems.  All aspects of the Prevention Program apply to all process areas of the facility.

Polymers Manufacture

Propylene is the primary feedstock for the polypropylene process.  This site has two process trains, containing a total of 3 reactors, with associated feed and recovery systems.  The significant inventories are contained in the reactors, degassing columns, vent recovery columns, and purification sieves.  All aspects of the Prevention Program apply to all process areas of the facility.

H-5 LPG Storage Area and LPG Railcar Staging Area

A mixture of propylene, propane, and ethane are brought into the facility via rail car and truck.  This process has facilities for staging railcars on site for floating inventory as well as facilities for unloading railcars and tank trucks into fixed storage vessels.  Additionally, this process has pumps for transferring this material to the purification units.  All aspects of the Prevention Program apply to all process areas of the facility.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Braskem America, Marcus Hook Polymers

Risk Management Program (RMP) Plan

Executive Summary



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Braskem America's ("Braskem") Marcus Hook Operations is committed to operating and maintaining our polypropylene manufacturing process in a safe and responsible manner. We have developed and implement programs to ensure the safety of our employees, the public, and the environment, including those that satisfy Braskem's corporate standards and applicable government requirements.  Braskem's programs satisfy or exceed all applicable requirements under both the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP). In order to ensure that our programs remain fully compliant, we periodically re-validate our Process Hazard Analyses ("PHAs") for covered processes to ensure that process hazards remain properly identified, understood, and adequately mitigated.  We also utilize these PHA revalidations to identify opportunities for further safety enhancements as needed. Braskem also conducts periodic compliance audits to ensure maintenance of administrative policies and mitigation controls to help prevent accidents and releases. The facility manager retains primary responsibility for safe operation of the facility.  In addition, all employees participate in safety related teams, projects, audits, and other activities and are trained to adhere to established policies and procedures. In addition, the Marcus Hook facility has a dedicated Emergency Response Team, consisting of fully trained members.  An Emergency Response Team is available during each shift.





Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled

The Braskem Marcus Hook facility manufactures polypropylene, used in many common household items and packaging containers. The raw material for the process is a liquid mixture of propylene, pro

pane, ethane, propyne, and propadiene. This raw material is offloaded via trucks and rail cars into the facility's storage area.  The site is equipped with a railcar storage area, where railcars containing raw material or finished product are kept prior to entering or exiting the facility. The raw material is subsequently processed in the Splitters separation area, and the resultant product is stored in the Cavern storage area. The purified ethane and propane streams are sold as products. The Facility combines the purified propylene stream with other raw materials, including hydrogen and triethyl aluminum, to produce polypropylene. The polypropylene, in the form of small pellets, is inert, non-toxic, non-hazardous, and not flammable. 



The facility maintains inventories of propylene, propane, ethane, propyne, and propadiene in quantities exceeding the 10,000 lb threshold for each constituent under the EPA RMP program. The facility does not maintain inventories of any other material in excess of its applicable EPA RMP threshold. The facility's RMP program addresses propylene, propane, ethane, propyne, and propadiene. These materials are flammable and potentially explosive if mixed with air in sufficient concentration. The facility handles these materials under pressure in both gaseous and liquid forms.





General Accidental Release Prevention and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

The elements of the facility's Risk Management and Process Safety Management programs are distributed among site personnel, coordinated by the Facility Manager and Lead Engineer. Facility employees participate as members of PHA teams, management of change (MOC) reviews, Pre- Start Up Safety Reviews (PSSRs), incident investigations, and similar activities.  In addition, Braskem coordinates with state and local agencies in addressing PSM and RMP program considerations, including through involvement of such agency personnel in facility training activities.  



Braskem also ensures that e

quipment design satisfies Braskem's RMP and PSM standards.  Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment are designed according to recognized industry standards and/or government requirements. 



In order to properly address Process Safety Information, Braskem documents relevant chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment information, and ensures that such information is maintained up-to-date, and made available to operating personnel.  Braskem also conducts PHAs to identify worst case scenarios and available preventative action(s). Layers of Protection Analysis: LOPA's are conducted where warranted by the identified hazards. The protection layers identified through each LOPA are maintained to ensure continued availability of adequate protection.



Operating Procedures: Operating procedures reflect safe operating practices for each affected process.  The facility updates all operating procedures to reflect any relevant changes.



Operator Training / Certification Program: A formal training and testing program is used to ensure that operators have proper skills and knowledge prior to independently operating the process.



Technical Staff Training and Support: Trained technical staff employees are available 24 hours per day to support operations. 



Maintenance Procedures: Specific procedures are developed to safely maintain process equipment. 



Mechanical Integrity Program: Vessels and other process equipment are periodically tested and/or inspected to ensure safe operation of process equipment, following recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements.



Management of Change: A management system is used to ensure that any modifications to affected processes are evaluated in advance of implementation to ensure that such modifications can be safely implemented and operated.



Pre-startup Safety Reviews: Reviews are conducted just prior to start-up of affected processes to ensure safe operation.



Incident Investig

ation: Facility procedures provide for investigation of any accident or incident to identify cause(s) and opportunity for corrective action(s).



Employee Participation: Employees are involved in prevention program elements.



Hot Work Permit: Procedures are used to ensure that welding, cutting and brazing are safely performed in areas where flammable or combustible material may be present. 



Compliance Audits: Periodic audits and assessments are conducted to ensure that process operations comply with applicable standards.



Facility operations comply with applicable requirements of the EPA RMP rule and OSHA's PSM standard.





Five Year Accident History

The facility has not experienced a qualified reportable release event, as described by the RMP regulations, during the five year period prior to this update of the RMP plan.





Emergency Response Programs

The facility maintains a written emergency response program for the site. The program consists of procedures for responding to releases of hazardous substances, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. In addition, the procedures address all relevant aspects of emergency response, including:

-- Proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures

-- Evacuation and shelter-in-place plans 

-- Procedures to ensure that all personnel are accounted for following an incident

-- Notification procedures for local emergency response agencies

-- Post-incident cleanup and decontamination procedures, and

-- Inspection, testing, maintenance, and use of emergency response equipment.



The facility utilizes a number of monitoring, detection, and suppression systems to prevent, detect, and mitigate fires and releases of hazardous materials. These include:

-- Computerized and local process control / alarm / interlock shutdown systems.

-- Hydrocarbon and flame detectors.

-- Automatic and manually activated water spray/sprinkler systems

-- Fire extinguish

ers

-- Centralized alarm system.

-- Communications Systems: Radios, Emergency Phones, PA system, Emergency Call Procedures.

-- Emergency Evacuation Procedures and Drills.

-- Fire Water System: Hydrants, Monitors, Hose Stations, and Backup Firewater system.

-- Diking and Burn Pits for Pyrophoric Liquids.



The Marcus Hook Site maintains a trained emergency response team to respond to fires, explosions, toxic vapor releases, spills, and medical emergencies. The emergency response team routinely trains and conducts drills to enhance their skills and tactics for responding to any accidental chemical release. 



The facility's emergency response program provides planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations. Detailed facility emergency response plans are developed and coordinated with the local emergency planning committee, fire department, police department, and other appropriate agencies. These plans include:

-- Emergency Reporting through the County LEPC (911).

-- Agency reporting: PA-DEP, National Response Center, State Emergency Operations Center.

-- Environmental Advisory Committee Reporting

-- "SARA" Hazardous Material Reporting, County and Local, State

-- Mutual Aid Agreements.

-- Drills with local Emergency Response Teams and area Company Response Teams.



The facility updates its emergency response program, as appropriate, in response to modifications to facility processes.





Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Braskem is committed to continuous improvement. Programs are in place to monitor the status of ongoing efforts and continually seek opportunities to improve. For example, the facility maintains the Braskem Employee Safety Team (BEST), a multi-disciplinary team with the goal of identifying methods to continuously improve Safety. A few notable projects include the following:



-- Development, maintenance, testing and monitoring of identified plant SCAI's (Safety Contro

ls, Alarms, and Interlocks) to greater protect the process and equipment.

- Development and implementation of a new procedure to respond to temporarily failed or bypassed control systems and to manage the resulting risk.

-- Installation of rail safeguards to reduce the potential that a railcar can be pulled away while connected to the off-loading rack.

-- Installation of safeguards to reduce the potential for a railcar to roll from the plant into a public roadway due to brake failure.

--  Education of Site Leadership on Human Reliability philosophy to promote across all work groups focus on effective solutions to problems and increased scrutiny of higher risk tasks.
